scenario:
Altria Group (MO) is a tobacco giant with a long history of market dominance, trading at 9.87 times forward earnings, significantly lower than the S&P 500's multiple of 24.2. The company's stock price has been affected by declining smoking rates and past missteps, but it is expanding its presence in alternative nicotine products, such as oral tobacco and nicotine pouches. Altria's dividend yield of 7.8% is among the highest in the S&P 500, with a payout ratio of 66.9%, suggesting a sustainable dividend.

Verizon Communications (VZ) is a telecom leader with a network that spans the nation, trading at 8.44 times forward earnings. The company has faced heavy spending on network upgrades and competition, but its cash-flow narrative has shifted, with free cash flow surging over the past 36 months. Verizon's dividend yield of 6.78% is attractive, with an 18-year streak of dividend hikes, despite a high payout ratio of 115%. The company is well-positioned to maintain its reputation as a reliable dividend payer.

Both Altria and Verizon have fallen out of favor with Wall Street, creating a "be greedy when others are fearful" scenario, with single-digit earnings multiples and high yields. These are market leaders with staying power, not speculative high-yield traps, with clear paths forward despite facing headwinds.
